fr:title.text: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These are mostly inspired by Zwart and Marsden's research into no-go theorems for distributive laws between algebraic theories [zwartmarsden2022].

I've been roughly translating properties of algebraic theories into the language of monad containers (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}), by considering:
Shapes s : S as "terms"
Positions p : P\ s as "free variables in the term s"
\iota as a "generic variable placeholder"
\sigma as a "generalised substitution"
\text {pr} as a "reindexing" of positions after a "substitution" This is not meant to be an exact translation; the idea is to get inspiration for properties of monad containers we might want to consider when proving things about monad container distributive laws.

A property of algebraic theories that is used in [zwartmarsden2022] is commutativity of disjoint substitutions, i.e. given terms s, s_0 and a substitution f where for all y, x 
otin 	ext {var}(f(y)) we always have that: s[s_0/x][f(y) / y 
eq x] = s[f(y) / y 
eq x][s_0/x]

The List monad container \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} satisfies this, which makes sense since it can also be represented by an algebraic theory. This also holds for coproduct, reader (trivially), state, writer, and probably many others!

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: No-Go Theorems for Distributive Laws
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{ Zwart_Marsden_2022, title={No-Go Theorems for Distributive Laws}, volume={Volume 18, Issue 1}, rights={https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0}, ISSN={1860-5974}, DOI={10.46298/lmcs-18(1:13)2022}, journal={Logical Methods in Computer Science}, author={Zwart, Maaike and Marsden, Dan}, year={2022}, month=jan, pages={6253}, language={en} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Coproduct monad container for a set E is given by the data 1 + E \triangleleft T where T\ (\text {inl}\ *) := 1, T\ (\text {inr}\ \_) := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {inl}\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inl}\ *)\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f &:= \text {inr}\ e\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is the unique monad container structure that you can give the container 1 + E \triangleleft T [uustalu2017]. This also happens to be a cartesian monad container. \text {pr} is well-defined up to function extensionality by induction on its implicit arguments.

The List monad container is given by the data \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= 1\\ \sigma \ n\ f &:= \sum _{i = 0}^n f\ i\\ \text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= \text {greatest } i \in \lbrack 0 .. n \rparen \text { where } \sum _{j = 0}^i f\ j \leq m \\ \text {pr}_2\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= m - (\sum _{j = 0}^{\text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m} f\ j) \end {align*}
Interestingly it seems to consist of the combinators S (a version with flipped arguments) and I. Is there some deeper connection to combinatory logic here?

The Writer monad container for a monoid (A, \otimes , e) is given by the data A \triangleleft \lambda \_ . 1 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= e\\ \sigma \ a\ b\ &:= a \otimes (b\ *)\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (*, *) \end {align*}
Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers. They are in bijection with compatible compositions of monad containers.

fr:title.text: There is only one representable monad container

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is only one representable monad container

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given the container 1 \triangleleft \lambda \_ . A, we look at the required data for a monad container. \iota and \sigma \ a\ b are trival (both are elements of 1). The equations for \text {pr} force it to be defined as the diagonal map: \text {pr}\ a := (a , a)
